docs.lead_paragraph: A law that imposes strict rules on assisted fertility will remain on the books, after the failure on Monday of a hard-fought referendum that rubbed into one of Italy's sorest spots: the relationship between church and state. The fight leading up to two days of voting on Sunday and Monday mobilized the nation's political and religious establishments like few others, as the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church -- including the new pope, Benedict XVI -- urged Italians to boycott the referendum.

headline.main: Italian Vote to Ease Fertility Law Fails for Want of Voters

docs.snippet: A law that imposes strict rules on assisted fertility will remain on the books after the failure of a hard-fought referendum.

byline.original: By IAN FISHER; Jason Horowitz contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Contrary to researchers' expectations, dysfunctional family relationships and poor communication styles appear to have little effect on whether young children become depressed, a study has found. While many children under 5 exhibit symptoms of depression, they often have not been exposed to known risk factors, experts find. And many children who are exposed to those risk factors appear to be resilient.

headline.main: In Childhood Depression, Not the Usual Suspects

docs.snippet: Contrary to researchers' expectations, dysfunctional family relationships and poor communication styles appear to have little effect on whether young children become depressed, a study has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: What is best for babies born with a severe neurological condition? Two doctors thought they knew. At a series of medical meetings in the 1970's, Dr. John Lorber argued that they should be left to die. Dr. John M. Freeman said they should be saved. The neurological defect in question, meningomyelocele, has since declined in incidence. But the issues that the doctors debated remain highly relevant in modern neonatal intensive-care units.

headline.main: Playing God With Birth Defects in the Nursery

docs.snippet: The issues that two doctors debated in a case from the 1970's remain highly relevant in modern neonatal intensive-care units.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Army's inability to recruit enough new soldiers to sustain its worldwide commitments is already serious, becoming alarming and poses a real threat to the future of America's all-volunteer military. That should be ringing bells in the Congress and the country and creating intense political pressure to address the underlying problems. They range from intolerable strains on morale and readiness as a result of having too few troops in Iraq to absurd and offensive policies that limit the Army's ability to make full use of its female soldiers and openly gay men and women wanting to serve their country. The requisite political energies aren't likely to be mobilized, however, if the Army keeps massaging monthly numbers to conceal the extent of the shortfall. In May for example, the Army originally hoped to send 8,050 new soldiers to training camps. Early in the month, as it became clear that new enlistments would not provide anywhere near that number, the target was dropped significantly, to just 6,700. Even that lowered target, it turns out, was missed by a whopping 25 percent, with only about 5,000 new recruits entering boot camp.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Army's inability to recruit enough new soldiers to sustain its worldwide commitments poses threat to future of America's all-volunteer military; scores Army for massaging numbers to conceal extent of shortfall, saying it must level with public and Congress about what it will take to meet nation's defense needs
docs.snippet: Instead of managing its recruitment numbers, the Army needs to level with the public about what it will take to meet the nation's defense needs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tired of celebrity coverage? Millions of readers can't get enough -- and neither can advertisers. Publishers of celebrity magazines that once looked to newsstand and checkout-aisle sales for almost all of their revenue are now experiencing surges in subscriptions and ad sales, bringing in the kind of money that could make a movie star jealous. Us Weekly's ad pages are up nearly 25 percent in the last year, and at Star Magazine, ads are up almost 17 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. In Touch Weekly's ads have risen nearly 22 percent.

headline.main: The Advertising Column; Forget About Milk and Bread. Give Me Gossip!

docs.snippet: A deluge of new celebrity-centered magazines in the past few years has quickly changed how the industry niche operates.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT sounds like a terrific solution to a thorny consequence of infertility treatment: take the extra embryos created during in vitro fertilization treatment for one couple, and donate them to other couples who are having trouble conceiving children but who desperately want them. The woman receiving the embryos could give birth to a child, and the donating couples, after having their own babies, could take satisfaction in their generosity.

headline.main: It's Not So Easy to Adopt an Embryo

docs.snippet: Conservatives use embryo donation as an argument against using embryos for stem cell research. But relatively few couples make such a donation to another couple.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though she is only in the third grade, Mamitu is one of the world's premiere obstetric fistula surgeons.

headline.main: The Illiterate Surgeon Op-Ed Special Report

docs.snippet: Even though she is only in the third grade, Mamitu is one of the world's premiere obstetric fistula surgeons.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Italy's most powerful men from politicians to bishops -- debated the ethics of the country's restrictive fertility law this week, Lorena Pennati lay gingerly in a hospital bed here, rubbing the sore spot where doctors had just removed nine of her eggs. Because of the law's strict limits on the use of eggs, sperm and embryos -- the subject of a contentious national referendum here this weekend -- Ms. Pennati, 34, is embarking on what doctors universally regard as substandard infertility treatment.

headline.main: Vote on Fertility Law Fires Passions in Italy

docs.snippet: Italy's most powerful men - from politicians to bishops - are debating the ethics of the country's restrictive fertility law this week.

byline.original: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

docs.lead_paragraph: James G. Butler, a lawyer who won the first jury verdict in a thalidomide case, died on May 26 at his home in the Hancock Park section of Los Angeles. He was 84. The cause was cancer, his family said.
docs.snippet: James G. Butler won the first jury verdict in a case involving the sleeping aid, which was banned after babies with birth defects were born to mothers who took the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old woman who had been unable to have children gave birth to a healthy daughter on Monday night in Alabama, about 15 months after receiving a transplant of ovarian tissue from her identical twin sister. The new mother, Stephanie Yarber of Muscle Shoals, Ala., is the first woman to have a baby after an ovarian tissue transplant from another person, her doctors said.

headline.main: Woman Has Child After Receiving Twin's Ovarian Tissue

docs.abstract: Stephanie Yarber of Muscle Shoals, Ala, who was unable to have children, gives birth to healthy daughter about 15 months after receiving transplant of ovarian tissue from her identical twin sister; is said to be first woman to have baby after ovarian tissue transplant from another person; had no need for antirejection drugs because her sister was perfect match genetically (S)
docs.snippet: The new mother, Stephanie Yarber of Muscle Shoals, Ala., is the first woman to have a baby after an ovarian tissue transplant from another person, her doctors said.
